info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 14.

(1, 1).clue: This impressionist was as skilled at painting people as he was at painting fields & sunsets

(2, 1).clue: Jack Handey "Deep Thought": "To me", this sport "is like a ballet, except, there's no music... and the dancers hit each other"

(3, 1).clue: Comfy casual brand for your dogs(4, 7)

(4, 1).clue: This state had the first hospital, the first circulating library & the first scientific society, endowed by Ben Franklin himself

(5, 1).clue: Hortense Powdermaker did fieldwork in this California place & wrote a book calling it "The Dream Factory"

(6, 1).clue: The only word in "The Pledge of Allegiance" that starts & ends with "N"

(1, 2).clue: One of the hundreds of portraits painted by this artist is seen here

(2, 2).clue: Hallelujah!  This "Late Night" bandleader co-wrote The Weather Girls' "It's Raining Men"

(4, 2).clue: In 1933 this state ushered in the first drive-in movie theater; it was located in Camden

(5, 2).clue: Ruth Benedict's study of this country began at the behest of the U.S. Office of War Information in the 1940s

(6, 2).clue: It's the first age you reach when you're surrounded by "N"s

(1, 3).clue: Life in the tenements of New York was a favorite subject of this Robert Henri "School"

(2, 3).clue: Neal McDonough was drafted to play Lt. Buck Compton in this WWII miniseries co-produced by Steven Spielberg

(3, 3).clue: Soft shoes to walk a mile in(9)

(4, 3).clue: In 1869 this state scored big with the first professional baseball team, the Red Stockings

(5, 3).clue: Among the Ndembu, Victor Turner studied these transitional "rites", like isolation for young boys

(6, 3).clue: A webcam on this university's School of Communications is pointed at Lake Michigan

(1, 4).clue: He painted the 1784 Neoclassical masterpiece seen here

(2, 4).clue: Sigourney Weaver made her debut as "Alvy's date outside theater" in this 1977 Oscar winner

(3, 4).clue: Comic book girl's namesake patent-leather shoes(4, 5)

(4, 4).clue: In 2001 it became the first U.S. state to ban hand-held phone use while driving

(5, 4).clue: A debate raged between Sahlins & Obeyesekere over whether the Hawaiians really thought this man was a god

(6, 4).clue: This "Dance" by the Pointer Sisters was featured in the film "Beverly Hills Cop"

(1, 5).clue: First name of the son seen here in a 1655 portrait by his father

(2, 5).clue: Before winning an Oscar for playing a shrink, he imitated Elmer Fudd singing Bruce Springsteen

(4, 5).clue: In 1989 this state elected the first African-American governor, L. Douglas Wilder

(5, 5).clue: Franz Boas organized the Jesup Expedition of 1902, exploring the relationship of people of these 2 continents

(6, 5).clue: A black widow spider's venom is classified as this 10-letter type of poison

(1, 1).clue: In "Civil Disobedience", this transcendentalist said, "That government is best which governs least"

(3, 1).clue: This room isn't just for actors; it's become part of many master bedroom suites

(4, 1).clue: This future Chief Justice was Dewey's 1948 running mate

(5, 1).clue: One of the Canterbury Tales tells of the Wyf of this place (which Chaucer spelled with an E on the end)

(6, 1).clue: It was really after this 1815 battle that Louis XVIII felt secure back on his old throne

(1, 2).clue: His "Beyond Good and Evil" is prophetically subtitled "Prelude to a Philosophy of the Future"

(3, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Paige Davis, host of TLC's Trading Spaces.)  Tips for doing this to your space include hanging mirrors, washing a wall with light & laying down area rugs

(4, 2).clue: The name of this 1868 loser is on the president's guest house

(5, 2).clue: In the first line of "The Canterbury Tales" this calendar word is spelled to end with a double L

(6, 2).clue: The roof of a factory & museum in Eden, N.Y. has the world's largest metal one of these toy instruments

(1, 3).clue: It may defy pure reason, but this philosopher seen here spent his whole life, 1724 to 1804, in Koenigsburg in East Prussia

(3, 3).clue: Before "dining room", this word that evokes tuxedos just means it's a separate room

(4, 3).clue: His 1920 run with James M. Cox didn't end his political career

(5, 3).clue: Chaucer spells this word to end in D-E-L; it's where a child of "half yeer age" lies

(6, 3).clue: Members of this Algonquian-speaking tribe live in Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas & Mexico, but not in Dogpatch

(1, 4).clue: This Scottish philosopher who died in 1776 denied that a miracle can be proved with any amount or kind of evidence

(3, 4).clue: A storage room by the kitchen where china & silver are kept is his "pantry"

(4, 4).clue: Bryan's 1900 running mate; his grandson with the same name also lost a race or 2

(5, 4).clue: One Chaucer poem is about "The Parliament" of these (spelled with a U in place of the W)

(6, 4).clue: They're the two pets seen here whose names differ by a letter

(1, 5).clue: This 20th century German wondered about the nature of being in works like "Being and Time"

(3, 5).clue: Named for its recessed panels, it's the type of ceiling shown; you can get a less elaborate version for the home

(4, 5).clue: This New Yorker was landslided with Goldwater

(5, 5).clue: The pilgrims are off to the shrine of Thomas Becket, whom Chaucer calls the "Blisful" this (with an I where we put a Y)

(6, 5).clue: Common Australian term for a newcomer on a sheep or cattle ranch

(0, 0).clue: Capital of the ancient Roman province of Galatia, it became a modern national capital in 1923
